 ISLAMIC FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF THE COMOROS PILOT AGRICULTURAL SERVICES PROJECT 1. INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Government of the Islamic Federal Republic of the Comoros (GOC) has requested IDA's assistance to help restore agricultural growth. The Government recognizes that a long term commitment is needed to achieve this goal and that innovative approaches must be sought to address the most binding constraints it faces with regard to agricultural development. This Pilot Project is proposed to support the first steps in this long-term process that is being embarked upon by Government. It will both seek to address the core constraints to agricultural development while serving as a vehicle for developing and testing innovative but viable solutions that could be adopted on a broader scale during a second phase. The total cost of the proposed Pilot Agricultural Services Project is estimated at about US$2.8 million equivalent, net of taxes and duties, with a foreign exchange content of US$1.4 million. IDA will finance US$1.6 million of total project costs, while IFAD and the GOC will contribute US$1.0 million and US$0.2 million respectively. 1.2 The project is derived from the GOC's Agricultural Sector Strategy ratified by the country's Federal Assembly in June 1994. A significant basis for the project comes from the results of a broad-based systematic consultation carried out with farmers, agricultural professionals and Government officials in the first half of 1995 during the preparation phase. A. BACKGROUND AND ECONOMIC SETTING 1.3 General Background. The Islamic Federal Republic of the Comoros is an Indian Ocean archipelago, inhabited by a largely homogeneous Islamic population of about 498,000 and a GNP per capita of US$ 490 in 1995. The economy is predominantly rural, and highly dependent on external assistance which averaged about US$118 per capita per annum over 1989-95. Agriculture accounts for 40 percent of GDP and provides the livelihood of 70-80 percent of the people and about 50 percent of total export earnings, with activities concentrated on the production of food crops as well as the three main export commodities (vanilla, cloves and perfiune essence). Services, mostly commerce and public administration, contribute about 49 percent of GDP, while construction and manufacturing represent around 11 percent. The industrial sector is limited to the processing of export crops and a few consumer goods supplying the domestic market. Tourism has started to develop, and shows promising growth potential. 1.4 The Comoros' social standards compare favorably with the average for sub-Saharan Africa. Life expectancy at birth is 54 years and the infant mortality rate is 95 per thousand. Between 1975 and 1995, primary school enrollment increased from 46 percent to 75 percent of the school-age group. However, high population growth averaging about 2.7 percent a year has
 2 put increasing pressure on basic social services, land use and the fragile ecosystem. Of the islands in the archipelago, Anjouan with a population of 496 inhabitants per square kilometer is the most densely populated. Grande Comore, the largest island, has a population density of 253/sq. km. and Moheli, the smallest one, has 128 inhabitants/sq. km. 1.5 Economic Setting. Since independence in 1975 the country has experienced considerable economic change in trying to adjust its economy to the external environment. Following a decade of growth bubble generated by externally-financed infrastructure projects, real GDP slowed significantly from an annual average of 6 percent in the early 1980s to 0.6 percent over 1985-95. This led to a decline in real per capita income by an annual average of about 2 percent during the past decade, and the emergence of chronic financial problems in the late 1980s. The decline in economic performance is a manifestation of the country's developmental constraints, which include a narrow export base, weak institutional capacity exacerbated by poor economic management, as well as an unfavorable private sector environment. To address its macroeconomic imbalances and remove some of the structural constraints to growth, the government launched an adjustment program in 1991. 1.6 The Adjustment Program. The adjustment program made considerable progress in liberalizing imports and removing price controls on several commodities. It also improved the environment for private sector activity and made some progress in reducing the fiscal burden arising from the parastatal sector. These led to major improvements in budgetary as well as external current account deficits in 1992-93. During that period, there was also a strong economic recovery, accounted for mainly by the improved performance of agriculture and manufacturing. 1.7 In January 1994, the Comorian Franc was devalued by 33 percent in foreign currency, in concert with the 50 percent devaluation that was effected by other CFA countries. The economy's response to this devaluation was mixed. Slow down of economic activities in trade and agriculture was responsible for a real GDP decline averaging 2.3 percent a year in 1994-95. Tourism growth had some compensatory effect in 1994, with tourist arrivals registering a 20 percent increase, but this was dampened by the coup in September 1995. Exports performance for traditional commodities was poor because of the depressed market of vanilla and cloves (resulting in a price collapse), even though new export products, such as new varieties of perfume essence and extracts, were starting to develop. With major shortfalls in revenues and an increase in current expenditures, the country's fiscal performance in 1994 and 1995 was weak. By end 1995, salary arrears for civil servants accumulated up to six months and external arrears reached $40 million. The inflation rate rose by some 20 percent in 1994 but stabilized at about 7 percent in 1995. In 1996, real GDP is expected to grow by about 2 percent as tourism has picked up and the private sector has started to regain confidence after the March elections. The rate of inflation is estimated to drop to 5 percent as prices have stabilized. However, public finances seem to remain difficult. 1.8 Economic reformns in Comoros have been complicated by the parallel efforts at introducing political reforms. The country's political landscape has been historically characterized by turbulence associated with attempts to reconcile modern governance with ancestral traditions. The latest phase of political change was initiated in 1990 with reforms aimed at bringing the country from one party rule to representative government. A multiparty Constitution was approved by referendum in June 1992. Since that time, however, the political
 3 situation has remained fragile, given the recent history of frequent changes in government and several coup attempts, the latest of which was in September 1995. 1.9 Presidential elections held in March 1996 represent a major landmark in the country's political transition process, and it is anticipated that this will usher in a period of stability. The prospects for 1996 are more positive and optimistic, with the economy expected to recover mildly by about 2 percent as the private sector starts to regain confidence after the March elections. New private investments are forthcoming in the hotel expansion, fishing and small manufacturing activities (soft drink). The new government has recognized the need for the country to improve its economic management and performance, and has started to take measures to improve budgetary revenues and cut expenditures, as well as create a more conducive environment for private sector investment through adoption of a comprehensive privatization program for the public enterprises. The devaluation of January 1994 has brought some improvement in the country's competitiveness, and continued membership of the Comoros in the Franc zone will provide a degree of stability based on prudent monetary policy. However, internal adjustment needs to be continued through compression of public expenditure and of the real cost of services and labor. The deepening of tax reforms is also needed to remove tax- induced distortions and strengthen government revenue base. The new government is preparing a second adjustment program to support these reforms as well as consolidate the gains from the earlier adjustment efforts and has requested support from the Bank and the IMF. A Structural Adjustment Credit and an IMF ESAF are being prepared for Board consideration in the first half of FY98. B. SECTORAL ASPECTS 1.10 The Agricultural Sector. Because of its predominance in the economy, the agricultural sector will likely remain the foundation of the Comoros' growth in the foreseeable future. Furthermore, the country possessed an unrealized potential for further growth. In addition to a favorable climate and known capacity to produce a variety of crops, the densely-concentrated patterns of rural population favor group and association development. The country's economic regime is amenable to the development of a market economy, despite its frailties; and there is a reservoir of underutilized technical knowledge and experience, within and outside the civil service, waiting to be tapped. 1.11 Policy FrameworkL The utilization of Comoros agricultural potential has been stifled by several policy, structural and institutional factors. On the policy front, distortions, including unfavorable fiscal/tariff regimes (i.e. high import duties on inputs, taxes on inter-island trade), and a currency regime that favored imports, resulted in a negative incentive structure for the agricultural sector. Although most of these distortions have been or are in the process of being corrected through the adjustment program which, for the time being, constitutes the Government's main instrument to address macro-economic issues, supply response has been slow due to the persistence of structural and institutional constraints. Most of these distortions have been or are in the process of being corrected through the adjustment program which, for the time being, constitutes the Government's main instrument to address macro- economic issues.
 4 1.12 Structural and Institutional Frameworl A key constraint to agricultural development, militating against a substantive response to the 1994 devaluation, relates to the inadequacy of the agricultural services delivery system. As corroborated by the results of extensive consultations conducted in the course of project preparation, the current system of extension as delivered by MPEPFE is unproven. The system is also unresponsive to beneficiary concerns/needs. As regards research, INRAPE, the agency charged with the country's agricultural research, has only very limited capacity and lacks both human and material resources. The only research activity carried in the recent past out has been through a small French-financed project, which has been able to study with good results the various farming 2 systems of the country . Some further support will be provided through projects currently financed by the European Union . 1.13 The Ministry of Agricultural Production, Livestock, Fisheries, Forestry and Environment (MPEPFE). The reorganization and downsizing of the MPEPFE in 1993 and 1994, which was part of the GOC's structural adjustment efforts, have not helped improve the capacity of the Ministry, particularly in relation to its ability to plan, monitor and execute its activities. The MPEPFE underwent a considerable reduction in its personnel from over 900 in the 1980s to 133 positions at present, as part of the GOC's structural adjustment efforts. While this reduction affected mostly staff under contract, it included some experienced staff in the Ministry's central services who opted for early retirement. This resulted in the significant weakening of the planning and monitoring capacity of MPEPFE, a function which will remain at the core of the Government's newly defined mission with respect to the agricultural sector. While the role of the private sector as investor is expected to increase over time, donor-financed investments in agriculture are likely to remain important in the Comoros for the foreseeable future, requiring institutional capacity for planning and monitoring the public expenditure program in the sector. In addition, frequent changes at the ministerial and often senior levels at the MPEPFE have seriously weakened the decision-making process at the Ministry and contributed to the drop in confidence in the rural areas toward the Ministry staff in the field. 1.14 Other agricultural development constraints include the prevalence of complex land tenure arrangements, ill-suited in the current socio-economic context, insufficient rural financing services, and inadequate infrastructure in the more remote areas. The problems associated with the land tenure system are diverse and stem in part from the co-existence of three legal systems (traditional, Islamic and colonial) and a variety of traditions affecting the inheritance of land. The situation is further complicated by: (a) the lack of specialized facilities or institutions to handle land tenure issues and formulate policy; (b) the lack of an operationally simple land titling or registration system; (c) the absence of formal leasing agreements between landlords and tenants; and (d) a demonstrated difficulty in enforcing property rights against illegal occupation of land (squatters). As part of its 1994 agricultural strategy, the Government has identified a number of measures to create a modern land tenure regime for the country, including the establishment of a new institutional framework. This task is on-going and there is a strong likelihood that, in the near future, work will be needed to ensure consistency between the institutional framework proposed as part of the agricultural strategy and the conclusions of the Law Review Commission. 1.15 On rural credit, the Comoros do not have a formal rural finance institution and a specific policy and legislation governing rural finance. Although rural credit facilities are currently being provided by two donor-assisted projects (the SANDUK project, financed by the CFD, and the IFAD-financed Appui aux Initiatives economiques de base). The five savings and credit facilities created during a recently completed FAO project are facing recovery delays and are not likely to be sustainable. The overall situation is characteristic of project-initiated credit initiatives, reflecting the absence of specific policy and legislation governing rural finance which leads to project designs that are contradictory and counterproductive. A national seminar, to review the activities in the sub-sector, was held in early 1996, the recommendations from which are expected to form the basis for needed policies and strategy. 1.16 To adequately respond to the challenges of agricultural development, the Government has adopted an agricultural strategy in 1994, whose principal objectives are: (a) to enhance rural incomes as a means of alleviating rural poverty and promoting food security; (b) to expand and diversify agricultural exports as well as broaden outlets for domestically-produced, non-traded food products; (c) to promote a self-sustainable, private-sector led agricultural development; and (d) to facilitate the viable and environmentally-sustainable utilization of natural resources. In the work leading to the formulation of its agricultural strategy, the Government has recognized the ineffectiveness of the dirigiste or top-down approach which characterized, up to recently, the relationship between the field staff and farmers . As a result, the decision has been made to adopt a more interactive, or participatory approach, in dealing with the farm population. This implies that, henceforth, active and constant consultation and exchanges will take place between the administration and its agents and the rural population, in order to define, formulate and implement developmental actions. 2. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT RATIONALE, OBJECTIVES AND DEscRIpTIoN 1. Project Rationale 2.1 The achievement of the Government's objectives for its agricultural sector requires (a) a long-term commitment and engagement to addressing the country's most binding constraints to agricultural productivity, while (b) seeking innovative approaches that stimulate private sector This situation was further confinned in the course of the surveys carried out in the proposed Pilot Project's preparation.
 6 involvement in the delivery of agricultural services to benefit small-scale farmers. To achieve these objectives, Government is continuing to intensify efforts geared towards restoring competitiveness of the agricultural sector (and of other productive sectors) through deepening and consolidation of economic reforms supported by the adjustment program. The government has also pledged to build a cost-effective agricultural service delivery system as well as strengthen its institutional capacity for sector planning and monitoring. To support the improvement of the legal framework, the government has established a Law Reform Commission to review, inter alia, existing statutes pertaining to ownership of land. A national seminar on rural finance was also held early in 1996 to obtain a better appreciation of the issues in this domain. The proposed Pilot Agricultural Services Project, is aimed at supporting Government's efforts towards refining, fine-tuning and implementing certain aspects of its agricultural development strategy. 2. Project Objectives 2.2 The specific objectives of the project will be twofold: (a) to produce through actual testing on the ground, replicable service systema that, if successful, could be established nation-wide, with full collaboration from the Government's partners in the donor community. The service systems to be tested include (i) a participation- based and results-oriented extension service, operable by either the private or public sector; and (ii) the use of private sector associations and the media to collect and relay market- and farm- related information, the cost of which could eventually be covered through advertising (of which there is still very little over the country's few communications media). (b) to support the strengthening of the country's capacity to implement its agricultural strategy through (i) the re-orienting and re-focusing of INRAPE's role as a collector and provider of technical information to extension agents and end-users, and a coordinator and provider of training services in the sector; and (ii) the improvement of MPEPFE's capacity for sector planning, monitoring and coordination, as well as (iii) the formulation of sub-sectoral policies and strategies to ameliorate rural finance and land tenure inadequacies. 3. Project Description 2.3 The proposed Pilot Project, to be implemented over a three-year period, will focus on improving agricultural services and strengthening institutional capacity in planning and monitoring the activities in the sector. 2.4 Agricultural services (US$1.3 million). The principal constraints to be addressed under this component will be the difficulties farmers experience in accessing relevant and timely information about crop-related technology, soil conservation and markets and in using it to their advantage. Based on the stated preferences of farmers, the project will (i) mainstream participation and client consultation in the delivery of efficient and cost-effective agricultural services; within this context, it will (ii) test the performance and effectiveness of private extension contractors working directly with farmers, against the existing public sector services; (iii) re-orient the country's "research" facility towards the collection, evaluation and propagation of technological information and making this information more easily accessible to all users; and (iv) support the development of groups and associations and enhance communications through national media on agriculture techniques and market related issues.
 7 2.5 Planning and Monitoring Support (US$0.3 million). The constraints to be addressed through this component will include: the weaknesses of the MPEPFE in the areas of planning, monitoring, sectoral policy formulation and general internal management. Planning and monitoring remain at the core of the Government's newly defined mission with respect to the agricultural sector. The government will continue to play a significant role in the preparation of the public expenditure program and coordination of investments in the agriculture sector, particularly those financed by external assistance. The quality and impact of these will depend largely on planning and monitoring skills within the Ministry. The project will, therefore, focus its activities in strengthening these skills and support the preparation of a suitable follow-on operation to the pilot, if warranted. In addition, it will also support studies and reflections aimed at reformulating rural credit and land tenure policies. 4. Detailed Features6 2.6 Agricultural Services. This component will include: (a) testing private sector delivery of extension services; (b) converting the country's research establishment into a depository/clearing house of agricultural technical information adapted to Comorian conditions; and (c) improving access to information through training, through the media and support to existing farmer organizations. 2.7 Agricultural Extension. The objective of this sub-component will be to test the delivery of extension advice to farmers through private contractors (NGOs, individuals, groups, specialized firms, etc.) selected by tender and operating under fixed-term contracts. The test will be based on the comparative evaluation, carried out by independent local consultants, of the performance of private contractors delivering extension services against that of existing public sector extension workers operating in separate villages. Selection of extension contractors and monitoring consultants, and review of the performance evaluation will be done jointly by the Government and Project Village Committees (PVC - para 3.4) representing the serviced farmers; similar committees will be established in the villages covered by the public sector workers. The appraisal mission has ascertained that there are qualified private sector individuals who will bid for this contract. 2.8 The project will finance the material investment costs and recurrent expenditures connected with the pilot extension activities. The fees of the private contractors selected on the basis of competitive bidding will be financed by the project. The salaries of the public sector workers will continue to be paid out of MPEPFE's budget. Equivalent operating resources and facilities will be given to both groups. Cost estimates of the private contractors have been calculated on the basis of three teams totaling eight individuals operating over an area covering a total of 12 or 13 villages. The public sector teams will involve a similar number of staff and villages. The financial provision for this activity will include contractual fees for the extension contractors, transport, office support and training for both private contractors and public sector workers. Resources will also be provided for vehicles and related operating costs for monitoring activities. 6 Implementation arrangements are given in Chapter 4.
 8 2.9 Technical support on agriculture related issues and message content, as well as training, will be provided by INRAPE to both private and public sector workers. Extension messages will initially focus on proven existing themes, including soil conservation, fertility restoration, plant protection, mixed farming8, establishment of live hedges9 and agro-forestry, as well as the marketing of produce. Fertilizers and other inputs are discussed in para 5.2 . Criteria on which to measure the performance of the extension workers will be based on the numbers of farmers participating and adopting recommended themes, on actual production data, intended for both consumption and market, on yield and income improvements, on utilization of inputs, etc. Data will be collected systematically by the independent monitoring team. The concept of two extension systems (public sector vs private sector) competing for "survival" should provide a dynamic environment in which farmers will be the foremost beneficiaries. The experiment is not intended to result in the elimination of the public sector extension service but to install an efficient and cost effective service. Hence, the public sector extension workers will be retained only in the areas where their performance is superior and also in areas not likely to be serviced by the private sector. 2.10 Research. To clarify INRAPE's role in the context of a significantly downsized MPEPFE, a specialized agency 0 will be recruited to help the Institute develop a Master Plan which will define its goals and appropriate organizational arrangements for the next five to ten years. The plan will take into account the Government's constrained resources, the farmers' expressed needs and the potential for the public extension service to be transferred to the private sector. WNRAPE will continue to provide farmers (both directly and through extension) and others with a ready access to agricultural information, especially concerning crops and other products for which the Comoros has a comparative advantage. In this capacity, INRAPE will collect, evaluate and re-package information in a usable form for extension agents, farmers and other users undertaking: (a) the strengthening of its documentation center; (b) the repatriation of information collected previously by foreign research institutes; (c) the production of technical papers on all crops that can be grown in the country; (d) the creation of a digest of all research findings; and (e) the production of an extension manual intended for both farmers and extension agents. The project will finance the above activities and help establish scientific relationships with other countries of the Indian Ocean region. It will also strengthen INRAPE's capacity to provide training both to its staff and to others. In response to a specific request by MPEPFE at appraisal, the project will finance crop protection activities, conducted by INRAPE, aimed, inter alia, at combating leaf spot (cercospora cajani), a widespread disease in the Comoros affecting both banana and pigeon pea stands. 2.11 Communications and Markets. This sub-component will help finance training in participatory approach techniques of members of groups and associations, extension contractors and public sector agricultural staff. An external consultant will be recruited to finish the training, started at preparation, of a pool of MPEPFE staff who in turn will train other nationals in these techniques. This experiment will be undertaken under contract between the MPEPFE and the agricultural section of the Chamber of Commerce for Industry and Agriculture, which will coordinate the activity. Data will be collected through the small but dynamic National Farmers' Union (SNAC) and analyzed and prepared for broadcasting by the Chamber of Commerce with the support of a local firm specialized in the preparation of radio programs. The project will finance: (a) training in the collection, analysis and preparation of data for market reports; (b) organization of information gathering; (c) support to media production groups for preparing market information programs; and (d) monitoring of results (through a private facility as for the extension experiment). The possibility of generating advertising revenues from farm broadcasts will be investigated by the monitoring consultants working in collaboration with the participants in this experiment. 2.12 Planning and Monitoring Support. This component will strengthen the MPEPFE's capacity to: (i) implement the 1994 agriculture strategy and prepare the public expenditure programs in the agriculture sector as well as sector development plans for each of the islands of the archipelago; (ii) coordinate, monitor and evaluate implementation of sector projects and activities; and (iii) carry out sector-wide studies. THE BANK GROUP'S ROLE A. LESSONS FROM IDA's INVOLVEMENT IN THE COMOROS' AGRICULTURAL SECTOR 4.1 To date, the Comoros received two IDA credits in agriculture. The Coconut Rehabilitation and Rodent Control Project (closed in December 1988) was designed to extend
 21 and improve coconut and copra production on the three islands. Despite positive technical results, the limited Government implementation capacity, low level of acceptance of recommended hybrids by farmers and the collapse of international copra prices prevented the project from achieving its objectives. The institutional and physical infrastructure put in place have not been sustainable. Important lessons that have been drawn from the project include: (i) project objectives should not be too technically complex and should adequately reflect economic and marketing factors; (ii) the agricultural innovations and technical recommendations to be introduced by the project should be tailored to the real needs of farmers and; (iii) the Government's limited implementation capacity should be addressed. 4.2 The Rural Services Project (closed in December 1991) which was co-financed with IFAD, aimed to strengthen the existing agricultural services at the time, to improve the planning, coordination and monitoring of rural development activities and included the expansion of livestock and forestry activities. The project was not successful and the resulting lessons indicate that efforts to strengthen institutions should: (i) be based on a well-defined and focused sectoral strategy; (ii) ensure coordination of donor contributions; (iii) address the problem of limited management capacity in the design of farmer support services; (iv) take into account the limited financial resources of Government to finance operating costs; and (v) identify the required training needs for the operation. 4.3 The above lessons are reflected in the proposed project through: (a) the consultation/ participation of beneficiary farners and villagers in project preparation and throughout implementation; (b) reliance on the private sector for implementation of most project activities, limiting the need to recruit additional Government staff; and (c) the involvement of other donors in the preparation and implementation process and provision for regular review, by IDA and other donors, of the Government's PEP. 1. RATIONALE FOR IDA INVOLVEMENT 4.4 The proposed project conforns with the Country Assistance Strategy, reviewed by the Board on December 14, 1993. The central objective of Bank assistance is to help the Comoros (i) reduce poverty by accelerating sustained economic growth (ii) develop human capital and reduce population growth; and (iii) protect the fragile ecosystem. These CAS goals are explicitly reflected in the design framework of the project. The project will foster the development of institutions and capacity in both the private and public sectors as well as assist in formulating appropriate policy and institutional frameworks for agricultural development. By building on previous IDA-intervention in the sector (Rural Services Project) and supporting environmentally-sustainable productivity growth and agricultural intensification, it will make a significant contribution to poverty alleviation. It will enhance the role of the Bank in donor coordination, and in the process, improve the efficiency of resource use through the mechanism of annual public expenditure. The results from this first phase of intervention will help clarify viable, sustainable and efficient frameworks for agricultural service delivery; and provide a basis for supporting a full scale follow-on operation in form of an integrated sector- wide agriculture and investment program.

PROJECT IMPACT ASSUMPTIONS, FINANCIAL/ECONOMIC ANALYSIS, SUSTAINABILITY AND RISK ASSESSMENT'9 A. IMPACT ON AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION 5.1 The Project Area. The 25 villages in which the pilot extension activities of the project will be carried out will occupy an area of approximately 22,400 ha, or about 29 percent of the country's total land area. Given the country's rugged and irregular topography, the wide range of soil quality, and excluding plantations (coconut), cash crops (ylang-ylang, cloves and vanilla) and other highly marginal non-cultivable areas, the cultivated area under food crops of the project villages will amount to approximately 6,800 hectares. Of this latter area, the appraisal mission has also assumed that about 1700 ha of food crop area, or slightly over 25% of the covered villages' cultivated area, will benefit directly from the technical and institutional innovations to be introduced by the project over the period. Based on an average of about 1.15 ha per household, the number of farm households to be covered by the Pilot Project will amount to about 1400. 5.2 Production Assumptions. Although small in size, farm production is generally diversified to provide variety and security against crop or market failure. Inter-cropping and multiple cropping, often on several and separate (even dispersed) plots of arable land, by any one farm household, are widespread. Rural households normally plant five crops or more per season, with up to nine crops during any one year. Four staple crops -- cassava, plantain, bananas and rice -- occupy 72% of the land. Annual crops such as bananas, plantain and cassava, are sparsely planted, leaving space for one or two associated crops, or a rotation of seasonal crops such as maize, yams, sweet potatoes, potatoes and pigeon peas, plus a few square meters for vegetables. Despite these well-adapted cropping patterns and the high intensity of land utilization in certain parts of the country, such factors as low plant density and variable soil fertility, the use of 19 This chapter summarizes the contents of Supplementary Annex 2 entitled "Financial and Economic Analysis".
 23 unimproved seed, and the low use of other inputs, result in very low yields for virtually all crops. Expressed in equivalent weight per hectare, yields are one-fourth to one-third those of countries in the region: rice yields vary between 300 kg - 800 kg/ha depending on location; cassava yields average 5.5 tons/ha; potatoes about 7 tons; plantain, 5 tons; and bananas, barely 3 tons. With proper advice, the use of improved seeds, minimum quantities of fertilizers and plant protection products, there is reasonable scope for raising yields over the medium and long term. Supplies of fertilizer, seed, planting stock and plant protection materials are available through the private sector at market prices. 5.3 Agricultural Output. The Pilot Project will seek to promote economically feasible and environmentally sustainable improvements to the farming systems, cropping patterns and overall resource allocation at farm level. It will rely initially on disseminating previously tested technology and farming techniques (para 2.9), many of which are already used by commercially oriented farmers, or readily available to smaller farmers. Technical messages will be tailored to the needs of each crop and to meet the needs of farmer groups. While the main thrust of the project will come from the supply of technical advice to farmers and the promotion of economical use of inputs, this will be supplemented with non-price incentives to stimulate increases of productivity. Providing market information through local and mass media is proposed under the project as a cost-effective means of reaching a large number of farms with periodic messages about demand and prices. Steps are already under way to standardize weights and measures in local markets and shops. Given their novelty and the lack of relevant information, the effects that these measures could have on production have not been quantified for the purpose of this analysis. 5.4 The main benefits will accrue to farmers through increases in foodcrop production. Based on calculat- s supported by above assumptions (the details of these calculations are in Supplementary Annex 2 dealing with financial and economic analysis), it is expected that crop production could be increase by about 24% over the project period. Yield and production increases are estimated conservatively: yields expected "with project" are indicative of those achievedpresently by larger and more resourcefulfarmers in the Comoros. B. C. IMPACT ON POPULATION, INCOME AND POVERTY 5.13 The target population for the Pilot Project is estimated at about 6000 families, of which some 1400 will benefit directly from the project's agricultural service related activities over the project's period. Family income estimates at the end of the Pilot Project are considered as indicative and represent modest increases ranging between 18% and 27% over the base year by year 4 of the project. The project will monitor progress carefully in order to determine if the proposed interventions are valid and if adequate incentives are given to farmers. There are, however, few alternatives. With prices of cash crops (vanilla, ylang-ylang and cloves) at about one-half those of the past in real terms, prospects for alleviating rural poverty remain conditioned by the present economic and financial circumstances.
 26 5.14 The Government has yet to produce a good representative household survey of incomes and expenditures although one is currently under way with support from the UNDP and the Bank. Until the data become available, the degree of rural poverty is not precisely known, but is considered to be acute for households whose total income is equivalent to less than FC 360,000 per year (the subsistence level in September 1995). The rural wage equivalent in Comoros is FC 750-800 per day, which on a monthly basis (26 days) amounts to about FC 20,000, the equivalent of FC 240,000 per year, about the same as the estimated subsistence level before devaluation. 5.15 Project measures that will be expected to have an impact on poverty will include: (a) extension messages and market information will initially support increased domestic food crop production (these are the crops produced by the poor) which will help improve the nutritional status. Another project premise is that facilitating poor farners' access to markets through improved information will serve to encourage production as well as, eventually, diversification into other food and export crops; (b) the sizable resources earmarked for training (almost 30% of project costs) in various forms, much of which is directed to the population, especially through extension and farmers' groups. The low level of education among the poor is given as one of the main factors for perpetuating poverty. 5.16 The impact of the foregoing measures will not be immediate, since it will take several years for markets to become fully accessible and competitive on each island, including commercial outlets for agricultural inputs and services. During the Pilot Project, the gradual effect of these changes on project beneficiaries will be monitored, as they influence the allocation of land and other resources in order to increase real income. The eventual impact of these measures will be expected to be achieved when, and if, a full development project is undertaken after the results of the Pilot Project have been assessed. D. IMPACT ON EMPLOYMENT 5.17 One potential economic benefit of the project, albeit not included in the calculations, will be the increase in farm level employment. Under-employment at the farm level is chronic, especially on small farms. With the project, however, and given the labor-intensive nature of crop production, the low level of mechanization and use of draft animals, between 500 and 1,000 person-years of supplementary on-farm employment is expected to be generated. Non- agricultural employment created by the multiplier-effect of increased crop production cannot be estimated. E. IMPACT ON PUBLIC EXPENDITURE 5.18 As part of its agricultural strategy, the Government is committed to bringing all existing projects in line with its strategic objectives. The plan to carry through this task was included in the strategy statement presented by the Government at the Donor Round Table of October 1994. Aligmnent is progressing but more work is needed particularly with regard to implementing the participatory approach and to ensure full harmonization between individual project objectives and those of the country's strategy. All donors have agreed to lend their support to this process through the projects they finance. The Pilot Project will play an important role in this context

Concurrently, and as part of the review of the progress in this regard, the Government will, no later than October 31 of each year, carry out, in consultation with all concemed donors, an annual review of its Public Expenditure Program for the agricultural sector and the environment. Assurances to this effect were obtained at negotiations. F. ENVIRONMENTAL CATEGORY 5.19 An environmental category C has been assigned to this project, as it is expected to engender a beneficial impact on the environment. Project activities will directly support efforts towards improving sustainability of agricultural production. Technical recommendations will support improved cultural practices and prioritize environmental protection measures (for which there are proven existing themes), including soil conservation, fertility restoration, plant protection, agroforestry, as well as the establishment of live hedges and other erosion control techniques. It will also continue to support fertility maintenance through composting, while encouraging farmers to use chemical fertilizers where appropriate. Chemical fertilizers will be restricted to those which have proven effective in the local context heretofore and with no known negative environmental effects. G. SUSTAINABILITY 5.20 Project design is geared towards expanding the scope for private sector involvement in the delivery of agricultural services, which supplements the weak public sector institutional capacity. There are also efficiency gains and increased cost-effectiveness accruing from the competition that will be introduced into the system, which in turn have an indirectly positive impact on the financial cost of the operations. If successful in developing replicable systems, the project could provide a basis for supporting a more sustainable operation on a broader scale, during a second phase of interventions. At this latter stage also, based on demonstrated results, cost-recovery measures could be considered, if feasible, to reduce the fiscal burden on the state. Other features of the project which foster long-term sustainability include the strengthening of the sectoral capacity for planning, programming and monitoring, and the enhancement of donor coordination (largely through the public expenditure review process). These interventions will facilitate the efficient programming of scarce budgetary resources and help improve the overall efficiency of resource use in the sector. In addition, the mainstreaming of client consultation in project activities, and the provision of support for strengthening capacity in participatory development techniques, helps ensure sustainability by capturing stakeholder interest and commitment in agricultural development activities. Finally, the contents of extension messages will be geared towards promoting sustainable utilization of natural resources. H. RISK ASSESSMENT 5.21 Major risks that the project may face include: (a) a low level of farmer participation and response due to the lingering lack of credibility of existing agricultural services; and (b) a low level of effective use of project-produced technological and market information. Regular monitoring of results and systematic consultation with the beneficiaries should ensure that feedback to project managers on the quality and impact of services enables them to address gaps in implementation. Measures to be put in place by the project include: (i) continuous monitoring
 28 through both private sector providers and public sector facilities; and (ii) continuing dialogue and mainstreaming the process of participation started during project preparation, involving will- be beneficiaries and project managers. 5.22 An additional risk facing this project stems from the budgetary constraints of the government and the possibility that the latter will be unable to sustain financing of its share even at the modest level projected. Public finance issues are being addressed in the context of the second structural adjustment program under preparation. The new government has already taken measures to improve revenue collection by strengthening the customs administration and to cut expenditures through continued civil service reform and reduction of civil servants allowances. This should help mitigate the risk of shortages in counterpart funding. In addition, the government is currently seeking alternative resources in the form of grant funds to cover its contribution in order to reduce its dependence on fiscal resources. 6. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Pilot Agricultural Services Project are to produce replicable service systems and support the strengthening of the capacity to implement its agricultural strategy. The project, to be implemented over a three year period, will contain two components. The agricultural services component will include: a) testing private sector delivery of extension services; b) converting the country's research establishment into a depository/ clearing house of agricultural technical information adapted to Comorian conditions'; and c) improving information access through training, media, and support to farmer organizations. The planning and monitoring support component will support the planning division, providing for computers, office equipment, staff training, and sector specific studies including: a rural finance study, a land tenure feasibility study, and an agricultural baseline study.
